items.title: eBridge: Digital Prototyping Tools
items.summary: Here's all the tools I mentioned during the eBridge Digital Prototyping Session from 02.03.2021. Overwhelmed by the amount of tools? Don't be! These are all just options and you get to pick and choose whatever suits your needs. Usually you at most ever need one…
items.content_html:
Here's all the tools I mentioned during the eBridge Digital Prototyping Session from 02.03.2021.

Overwhelmed by the amount of tools? Don't be! These are all just options and you get to pick and choose whatever suits your needs. Usually you at most ever need one tool per category, and maybe Figma or its alternatives already get everything done that you want to achieve (it comes with a great community, a helpful Youtube Channel, a free plan, free pro features for students, an extensive plugin ecosystem and a whole lot more). Have fun!

Static UI Design

Figma https://www.figma.com/
Sketch https://www.sketch.com/
Adobe Xd https://www.adobe.com/de/products/xd.html
Invision Studio https://www.invisionapp.com/studio

Tools to makestatic designs more dynamic

Framer/ Framer X https://www.framer.com/
Bravo Studio https://www.bravostudio.app/

Both these tools offer Figma imports, so you could start designing in Figma and later make your prototype more dynamic by importing your screens into Framer or Bravo Studio.

Prototyping Tools

These tools focus on dynamic prototypes with advanced capabilities like animations etc. They also offer prebuilt components that can be drag and dropped to rapidly create visually appealing prototypes. There are so many of these that I can't list them all, but you can find a nice overview on this site: https://uxtools.co/tools/prototyping

Marvel https://marvelapp.com/
UXPin https://www.uxpin.com/
Proto.io https://proto.io/
Protopie https://www.protopie.io/
Axure https://www.axure.com/

No-Code App Builders

These are similiar to web site builders like Wix, Weebly, Webflow etc., only that instead of sites you can build out fully functioning apps. This can be great for simple apps that only store and display data, but since you're "programming" using the visual editor of the app builder, you can quickly run into limitations of the builder itself. It's worth to take a look into the app examples advertised by the app builders to get a better feeling of what they can (and can't do) in terms of features. I'd encourage you to think through your ideal app first so that you don't end up sacrificing your initial vision by staying within the boundaries of what these no-code app builders can offer.

Glideapps https://www.glideapps.com/
Adalo https://www.adalo.com/
Bubble.io https://bubble.io/

3D-Design

This is a bit of a niche, but depending on the product this can be a very impressive demonstration and allow for a whole new understanding of a product through a 3D representation. Traditionally something you'd approach using CAD-tools, there's new tools in the space that make 3D-design more approachable even for non-technical people.

Spline.design http://spline.design/
Vectary https://www.vectary.com/

User Testing

While in person testing is preferable to observe users reactions and to interview them in a face-to-face environment, there are ways to test digital prototypes with remote testers:

Maze.design https://maze.design/figma/
Quant-UX https://www.quant-ux.com/

Landing Pages

It has gotten much easier to build up a digital presence over the last years. Here's some tools/ services you can take a look at if you want to bring your product/ startup page online.

Simple Landing Pages Wix (general purpose)
Umso(generated startup page)
Carrd (simple one pager)
More Complete Sites Wordpress + Elementor
Advanced Visual Editor Webflow

items.title: AWS Educate: Cloud-Services for Students with 100$ in free AWS credits
items.summary: With AWS Educate, Amazon provides free cloud resources to students and faculty staff in order to learn about the AWS cloud and gain experience with AWS services. In addition to various video guides on different career paths (e.g. Machine Learning Engineer, Data Scientist, App Developer,…
items.content_html:
With AWS Educate, Amazon provides free cloud resources to students and faculty staff in order to learn about the AWS cloud and gain experience with AWS services. In addition to various video guides on different career paths (e.g. Machine Learning Engineer, Data Scientist, App Developer, DevOps Engineer, Cyber Security Engineer, etc.), university members also receive AWS credits that can be used for cloud services via the AWS console. For students of the Munich University of Applied Sciences, this amounts to $100 per year, which can be used as a kind of playground without having to deposit one's own credit card.

The AWS platform offers a variety of useful services related to hosting (websites, web apps, backends), authentication, cloud resources (computing power, storage space) and cloud infrastructure (databases, API gateways, etc.).

How to obtain your AWS credits

The first step is to register for AWS Educate with your university email address. This can be done in the dialog that can be found here. For students that are not enrolled at the HM, the offer may or may not be available. After choosing your role ("student"), AWS Educate asks for a number of information, e.g. name, country, date of birth, email and expected end of studies.

After the registration is completed, it may take 1-2 days for your account to be enabled as AWS checks registration and student status. After that you will receive an email which should look like this:

You can set your AWS Educate password using the link in the email. After accepting the terms of use, you will be forwarded to the AWS Console by clicking on the tab "AWS Account":

Success! You've enabled your account and you can now annual Cloud Credits. It is worth to took a look at the FAQs in the Workbench, e.g. the following hints should be considered:

  • All services are only supported in US East (N. Virginia) [us-east-1] region.
  • Remember to shut down your instances when not in use to make the best use of your credits.

Do you plan to launch your own projects on AWS and are interested in getting support and guidance? The HM maintains a close partnership with AWS through the Digital Transformation Lab (DTLab) . The DTLab can provide you with contacts and support around AWS to help you get started!

Did you know? In cooperation with AWS, the DTLab organizes challenges every semester that allow students use the Amazon platform in order to tackle a series of societal problems. Head over to the DTLab-Site in order to to learn more about it.

items.title: Precelerator goes digital: This is what you can expect from the launch of the brand new offer at the HM
items.summary: With the launch of the new website and this blog, the Precelerator, the new offer of the Strascheg Center for Entrepreneurship at HM digital, starts the new semester. Here you can find out for whom the new Precelerator is intended and which Precelerator offers will be available soon.
items.content_html:
With the launch of the new website and this blog, the Precelerator, the new offer of the Strascheg Center for Entrepreneurship at HM digital, starts the new semester. Here you can find out for whom the new Precelerator is intended and which Precelerator offers will be available soon.

The Precelerator is a brand new initiative at the Strascheg Center for Entrepreneurship (SCE) targeted at makers and innovators that don't necessarily aim for founding their own startup, but instead are looking for help and resources to get their project off the ground. Providing both technical staff as well as mentors and coaches through the SCE, the Precelerator is the ideal place to connect with others and to work on innovative ideas and initiatives.

If you want to learn more, keep your eyes out for our digital launch in November, we're excited to share with you what we have been working on over the last months!

Call To Action

Interested in joining the precelerator as a member or collaborator? We're always open for project suggestions, get in touch using our email precelerator@sce.de and we'll get back to you as soon as possible.

items.title: Website-Builders for Landing Pages
items.summary: No online marketing campaign can nowadays do without a landing page. Especially for smaller companies a website is the center of their online presence, but often there is a lack of budget for a professional implementation. Fortunately, there are resources and tools that make it easy to create a landing page for your project or start-up. This blog post collects the most popular website builders, with which you can quickly and easily launch your own landing page.
items.content_html:
No online marketing campaign can nowadays do without a landing page. Especially for smaller companies a website is the center of their online presence, but often there is a lack of budget for a professional implementation. Fortunately, there are resources and tools that make it easy to create a landing page for your project or start-up. This blog post collects the most popular website builders, with which you can quickly and easily launch your own landing page.

Drag&Drop Website-Builder

Modern website builders do not require any code at all. They allow you to hack together your own pages by using visual drag and drop editors without any programming. Such tools often offer ready-made templates into which users can insert their own content. Well-known players in this market are Carrd, Wix, Squarespace, Wordpress and Webflow, some of which will be briefly compared below:

Carrd: Carrd is particularly suitable for one-pager, i.e. landing pages or similar, which are not too complex. Carrd does not require any programming knowledge and offers a variety of templates which can serve as a starting point. Carrd offers a free plan as well as a very affordable pro-plan.

Pros: fair pricing, Free-Plan in order to try out (indefinitely), well-crafted templates

Cons: mainly useful for one-pagers (not blogs etc.), limited adaptability of templates

Wix: Often belittled as the "McDonalds of website builders", Wix promises an easy creation process for your own website. Wix is primarily aimed at people without any programming experience and abstracts any implementation details away through its visual editor. Pages can be hacked together via Wix' drag & drop builder. As often the case with other website builders, Wix pages cannot be exported as code. As a result, owners of Wix pages have to pay a monthly subscription fee to Wix in order to edit their pages. Wix offers numerous plugins to add features to pages and provides templates and a custom logo maker.

Pros: simple editor, aimed at people without an IT background, easy entry bar

Cons: dependence on Wix, after initial selection it is difficult to switch between templates, sites not always mobile-friendly, SEO of sites below average

Weebly/ GoDaddy: comparable to Wix.

Squarespace: Squarespace is another player in the website builder market. Squarespace main selling point are its professional templates which are designed by Squarespace itself and qualitatively stand out from the competition. Squarespace focuses on minimalist but high-quality design, all templates are mobile-friendly from the start. Squarespace offers detailed guides and resources and additionally provides live chat support.

Pros: high-quality templates, ability to export code, ability to change themes

Cons: no dedicated free-plan, only try-out phase, more pricey than alternatives, limited editing capabilities of templates

Wordpress: Originally started as a blogging platform, Wordpress now operates a significant proportion of all websites worldwide. With a very user-friendly process for content creation and an extensive plugin system, Wordpress has a low entry threshold, but still countless customization options. Wordpress has a large number of ready-made free and paid themes and its popular page-builder Elementor. The only downsides of Wordpress are its speed (often sluggish depending on hosting and number of plugins) and security gaps caused by outdated or amateurishly implemented plugins.

Pros: Widespread, large community, many useful templates

Cons: can be quite slow, plugins must be updated

Webflow: Calling itself the "Design Tool of the future", Webflow offers enormously extensive configuration and design adaptations. It is a browser-based website builder with a large variety of templates. Webflow is especially suitable for people who already have some website experience, as many concepts from website programming can also be found in the visual Webflow editor. Webflow allows you to export the created page as code and also offers numerous learning resources to get started (Webflow Community, Webflow University).

Pros: Powerful editor, which also allows more complex designs, many templates

Cons: for simple landing pages overkill, correspondingly higher pricing

The choice of a suitable website builder ultimately depends on your own requirements, the following questions should be answered for yourself:
  • What budget do I have available?
  • How much experience do I have with the implementation of websites?
  • How much value do I place on ready-made templates?
  • Do I want to be able to remodel or even move my site, or do I throw it away in an emergency and start over again?
Are you interested in launching your own website and have questions or need support? We at Precelerator, the new service for tinkerers, coders and future entrepreneurs at SCE, will help you to get your project on the right track!
 
Send us a message over to precelerator@sce.de and we'll get back to you as soon as possible.

items.title: Design Tool Figma: clickable prototypes made easy
items.summary: Traditionally, there has been a gap between the design and development of applications and websites: while designers often use image editing software such as Photoshop to provide static layouts and design templates, developers usually work with code in order to create clickable and interactive prototypes. To…
items.content_html:
Traditionally, there has been a gap between the design and development of applications and websites: while designers often use image editing software such as Photoshop to provide static layouts and design templates, developers usually work with code in order to create clickable and interactive prototypes.
 
To bridge this gap, a variety of advanced design tools have emerged in recent years to make the design process more interactive, collaborative and closer to the development process. Leading Players in this area are Sketch (OS X), Adobe Xd (MacOS/ Windows) and the web-based tool Figma that this blog post is gonna dive in deeper into.

What is Figma?

Figma helps teams create, test, and ship better designs from start to finish.

Figma is a relatively young company in the design market and follows the mission to rethink design and make it more accessible to both designers and developers. The low barriers of entry (free for personal use, web-based, easy to create and share prototypes) make Figma ideal for projects of all types involving the design of digital applications (apps, websites, etc.). Figma eliminates the need for traditional mockup/wireframe tools by quickly creating realistic interfaces with a visual editor that look very similar to "real" applications.
 
To get a first impression of Figma's approach, it is worth taking a look at the following teaser (1:35):

Figma: Getting Started

In order to get started with Figma, head over to  https://www.figma.com/ and create your account. Students and educators get benefits when signing up for Figma: using your university email adress you're able to obtain the Figma Education plan (unlimited projects and unlimited editors for up to two years) if you apply or register using this link.

Since Figma is web-based, you will be taken directly to the application, where after some setup questions a short introduction is waiting for you:

If you prefer to work with the desktop app, you can find it in the web app via the menu -> "Download desktop app". For inspiration, it is worth taking a look at the example projects found in the "Recent" tab of the desktop app in the menu ("Prototyping in Figma", "Figma Basics", "Wireframing in Figma").

In order to collaborate with your team, invite other students to your project. For more information on how Figma allows for collaborative editing and commenting, check out their Collaboration page!

Features

Even in the Free Plan, Figma allows you to invite project members to join projects and collaborate with them. A key feature of Figma is the ability to work together on a design project, regardless of the operating system. This allows all stakeholders to edit and comment on the project in order to develop a design together as a team.
 
Created designs can be made available to others as a clickable prototype via the "Share" feature and can be tried out via a shareable link or even mobile via the "Figma Mirror" app.

Figma offers a lot of advanced features that allow for a better structure for larger projects and that can be highly beneficial for a more efficient workflow within Figma. I'd recommend taking a look at the relevant tutorials and in-depth Office Hours that Figma has on their Youtube channel. You can find a selection of the most recent ones in the upcoming table: 

Auto Layout Tutorial Office Hour
Constraints Tutorial -
Components Tutorial Office Hour
Arranging Components Tutorial -
Variants (of components) Tutorial Office Hour
Smart Animate Tutorial -
Prototyping & Transitions Tutorial -
Vector illustrations Tutorial 1, Tutorial 2 Office Hour

Tips & Tricks

Design tools often have a certain learning curve due to their many different areas of application, but in Figma, this is limited to the minimum. The following key combinations and tips for using Figma are helpful for getting started:

Scroll (mouse) Scroll up/down
Ctrl+ scroll (mouse) Zoom in/out (zooms towards where the mouse hovers)
Space+ Drag (mouse) move view
Shift + Click (mouse) highlight several elements at once
Shift + Drag (mouse) Resize element without changing the side ratios
Alt + Drag (mouse) duplicate element
Ctrl + G Group elements so they can be dragged&dropped together

For a quick start, we also recommend a look at the Figma Community-Section, where Figma users can obtain ready-made wireframes, templates, picture sets and icons. Especially for Figma beginners, you can find some quickstart templates here, which can also be used as inspiration for your own projects.

Resume

Figma impresses with a generous free plan, collaboration possibilities for teams, demonstrability through divisible links and a very active community that provides sample resources and tutorials on a large scale. With Figma, you can quickly develop clickable prototypes that look surprisingly close to finished applications, making it the tool of choice for all those that want a presentable demo of their idea without writing a line of code.

It's easy to get started with, and with it's vibrant community there are tons of guides and resources out there that can serve as a quick starting point for your and your application.

Are you working on your own prototype and would like some guidance around your design- or prototyping project? Contact Fabio from the Precelerator-team for a quick coaching session: fabio.maienschein@sce.de

items.title: No-Code Tool Glide: Generate mobile-friendly apps from Google Sheets
items.summary: Spreadsheet software such as Excel and Google Sheets is an essential tool for data collection in a large number of projects, but spreadsheets are often not easy to grasp and tend to be difficult to use on mobile. At the same time, spreadsheets are the…
items.content_html:
Spreadsheet software such as Excel and Google Sheets is an essential tool for data collection in a large number of projects, but spreadsheets are often not easy to grasp and tend to be difficult to use on mobile. At the same time, spreadsheets are the most common source of data in all kinds of imaginable projects which is a source of frequent annoyance.
 
This is exactly the use case that the American startup Glide addresses and promises the automatic generation of mobile-capable web apps straight out of Google Sheets. Programming knowledge is not necessary and everything you need is provided by Glide. Examples of Glide apps can be found in the extensive template gallery, which contains demo apps for different use cases (e.g. a conference timetable, a CRM or a task tracker).

Technical Implementation

Glide uses Google Sheets to store the app's data and generates a so-called progressive web app for the user, ultimately nothing more than a mobile web application that smartphone users can install on their home screen. This saves Glide the detour via the respective App Stores, instead Glide can generate a URL which users can use to install the created app. Due to the availability via a link and the execution in the browser, Glide apps run automatically on any mobile device regardless of the operating system (Android, iOS, etc.). After clicking on the respective link, the user is prompted to add the app to the home screen of his smartphone. The trick: since Progressive Web Apps are web applications so the app does not need any storage space (since unlike native apps, it runs directly in the user's browser).
 
A visual editor allows Glide users to customize the look and feel of the app, so that the display and positioning of content can be adjusted as desired. Data can be manipulated in the associated spreadsheet which means that adding, editing and deleting entries can be done within Google Sheets.

Pricing

Glide offers different Pricing-Plans, the Personal Plan with Glide logo and some restrictions (<500 records, <1000 edits per month, <100 MB storage space for pictures etc.) is provided free of charge. Professional apps without branding and with additional features such as upstream authentication, a dedicated domain, up to 25000 records, 10 GB of memory and unlimited edits are available for around 30€ per month.

Resume

Overall, Glide provides an impressive feature set for no-code apps, and with Google Sheets as the primary data storage and Glide's visual app editor, it is especially suited for users who have no programming experience. Due to the technical implementation as a progressive web app, Glide apps are very easy to divide and install, so as a result a presentable application can be created with just a few hours of work. Due to the Glide branding, the free plan is only suitable for more professional projects to a limited extent, but with 30€ per month, the pricing for pro apps is low compared to self-implementation or commissioning a developer with the app development. Glide positions itself prominently in the area of simple list-based apps, but with features such as the display of content such as images or maps, it also offers content that goes beyond pure lists. Whether Glide is a sensible choice definitely depends on the type of application, so it is worth taking a look at the sample applications in order to get a better feel for the features and limitations of Glide.

Call To Action

Are you interested in launching your own project and have questions or need support? We at Precelerator, the new offer for tinkerers, coders and future entrepreneurs at SCE, will help you to get your project on the right track!
 
Send us a message over to precelerator@sce.de and we'll get back to you as soon as we can.

items.title: No-Code Tool Bubble: Visually create web apps
items.summary: Whether TripAdvisor, AirBnB or Shopify: Web-apps represent the most important platform for consumer and B2B applications alongside mobile apps. Until a few years ago, this area was still dependent on complex web development, but more and more so-called no- or low-code platforms are emerging which…
items.content_html:
Whether TripAdvisor, AirBnB or Shopify: Web-apps represent the most important platform for consumer and B2B applications alongside mobile apps. Until a few years ago, this area was still dependent on complex web development, but more and more so-called no- or low-code platforms are emerging which allow even less technically skilled users to create web applications.

One of these no-code platforms is Bubble, a young start-up from New York. The platform promises to simplify the creation of fully functional web applications using the company's own visual programming language. Web applications created using Bubble are hosted by Bubble itself and are accessible to users via regular web URLs.

Features

Bubble offers various features such as authentication (logon/registration), storage, retrieval and processing of data, connection to APIs (like interfaces to any backend) and the connection of payment providers (e.g. Stripe). Created web applications can be built responsive, i.e. suitable for all screen sizes, so that they can also be displayed appropriately on smartphones and tablets.

Principles of Bubble

The user interface of bubble applications can be assembled from a library of interface components (buttons, text fields, etc.) by drag and drop. So-called workflows regulate the processes that should be executed by the application during user interactions. 

Learn how to use Bubble

Bubble offers a lot of resources to help you get started. Go to Bubble.io to create your own account and get started. There's 10 quick tutorials that show you step by step to create little applications such as a shopping list, iTunes song search and an image gallery that users can upload images to.

If you want to work on a Bubble app as a team, go to Settings -> General -> Application rights and change the dropdown from "Private" to "Everyone can edit". Now if you copy the link of your Bubble app (while it's open in the editor), you can share it with your team so you can all edit the same application!

For further resources to learn more about Bubble, check out the following links: 

Introduction and documentation https://manual.bubble.io/
Interactive Lessons https://bubble.io/lessons
Advanced Lessons in order to imitate popular web apps https://bubble.io/how-to-build
Assistance/ Community https://forum.bubble.io/
Marketplace for templates and plugins https://bubble.io/marketplace
Showcase gallery for inspirations
 https://bubble.io/showcase

Pricing

Free Plan with branding, no own domain free
Personal 25$/month
Professional 115$/month

More information in regards to pricing over at https://bubble.io/pricing

Review - Bubble, the right platform for your MVP?

In-depth Guide for Bubble

Call To Action

You are interested in launching your own project and have questions or need support? We at Precelerator, the new offer for tinkerers, coders and future entrepreneurs at SCE, will help you to get your project on the right track!
 
Send us a mail to precelerator@sce.de and we will get back to you as soon as we can.

items.title: Recommended (Online-) Ressources for your side projects
items.summary: Students, as future workers and decision makers, are an ideal target group for software tool vendors, so many vendors have started to provide generous free trial or free plans to convince them of the quality of these offerings. Such resources are ideal for smaller projects…
items.content_html:
Students, as future workers and decision makers, are an ideal target group for software tool vendors, so many vendors have started to provide generous free trial or free plans to convince them of the quality of these offerings. Such resources are ideal for smaller projects to build on and gain experience with these technologies. In this lesson you will learn about various offerings and resources that you can use for your next side project!

1) Free tools for design and development

The following free tools are especially popular within designers and developers:

Visual Studio Code: The open source code editor from Microsoft, which is a general-purpose weapon for development projects due to its simple, but powerful user interface and can be adapted for all kinds of use-cases with its rich plugin ecosystem.

Figma: A modern design tool that allows the design of user interface mockups and provides clickable prototypes that can be shared with a link. Figma also emphasizes collaborative features that facilitate a common design and review process. Check out this blog post to help you get started with Figma.

Git: Git has become the most popular versioning and source code management tool in recent years and is essential for all coding projects. Hosted source control platforms like GitHub und GitLab allow you to store source code publicly (or privately), and to host it directly (GitHub Pages) or as the starting point for Continuous Integration/ Continuous Deployment (GitHub Actions).
The HM also offers its students a self-hosted GitLab instance, that all students with HM credentials (@hm.edu) can use.

2) Free offers for hosting and cloud infrastructure

The following providers are particularly recommended due to their generous free plans for hosting smaller projects and websites:

AWS Educate - Student access to Amazon's cloud services with $100 starting credit (no credit card required). Follow this blog post to claim your own AWS resources.

Netlify - extremely simple deployments of front-end resources (websites and applications) directly from the source code management or alternatively via drag & drop of local files

Firebase - Backend-as-a-Service service from Google that provides free quotas for services such as authentication, hosting and storage (Firestore).

Heroku - Hosting of web applications (free plan with restrictions, option of a free hobby dyno via GitHub Student)

Amazon Webservices, Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud Platform - even the large business clouds offer free plans, often without a credit card (e.g. Azure Student).

3) GitHub Student Developer Pack

Probably the largest collection of free software resources, the GitHub Student Developer Pack deserves a mention in any such list. Students with valid university addresses will receive a variety of offers after verification by GitHub. These include free domains (.me and .tech, limited to 1 year), cloud resources (AWS, Azure, Heroku), a cooperation with Unity (free assets), professional development environments for a variety of programming languages (Jetbrains) sas well as one to six month accesses for Tech course platforms (FrontendMasters, One Month, Flatiron School).
 
A complete overview of all included freebies can be found here, also it's worth taking a look into the gallery of projects built with resources from the GitHub Student Pack.

Call To Action

Are you interested in launching your own project and have questions or need support? Our team at the Precelerator, the new offer for tinkerers, coders and future entrepreneurs at SCE, will help you to get your project on the right track!

Are you working on your own prototype and would like some guidance around your design- or prototyping project? Contact Fabio from the Precelerator-team for a quick coaching session: fabio.maienschein@sce.de
